snippet: A broad array of factions have turned against the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, known as ISIS, in a showdown over tactics, power and ideology.
abstract: Array of insurgent factions have turned against the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria in dispute over tactics, power and ideology within Sunni jihadist movement; clash, which has drawn fighters from across the globe, pits pragmatists against idealists, and is viewed by many as both fight for character of jihadism as well as common turf war.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by an employee of The New York Times from Aleppo, Syria, Karam Shoumali from Istanbul, and Hwaida Saad and Mohammad Ghannam from Beirut.

lead_paragraph: A broad array of factions have turned against the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, known as ISIS, in a showdown over tactics, power and ideology.

headline.main: Syria Rebels Turn Against Most Radical Group Tied to Al Qaeda
headline.print_headline: Syria Rebels Turn Against Most Radical Group Tied to Al Qaeda
